metadata.case_name: State of Orissa v. Durga Charan Das

facts.text: Respondent Durga Charan Das joined as an Assistant in the old Bihar Orissa Secretariat prior to the formation of the Province of Orissa.
Province of Orissa formed on 1st April 1936; respondent transferred to Orissa Secretariat, Home Department.
Respondent promoted to Junior Head Assistant and Senior Head Assistant in due course.
On 24th April 1954, respondent temporarily promoted as Registrar in Supply Department while holding post of Senior Head Assistant.
On 22nd December 1954, respondent reverted to substantive post as Head Assistant in Home Department.
On 3rd February 1956, respondent again promoted to officiate as Registrar in Supply Department.
In June 1957, respondent promoted to officiate as Assistant Secretary in same Department.
On 14th October 1958, respondent confirmed as Registrar in Orissa Secretariat.
Respondent retired from service on 17th October 1959.
At retirement, pension fixed by State of Orissa at Rs. 190 per month by reference to 14th October 1958 confirmation date as Registrar.

Respondent claimed pension refixation deeming confirmation as Registrar from 24th April 1954 (Rs. 290 p.m.) or alternatively 23rd August 1956 (Rs. 240 p.m.), as junior Mr. J.N. Dutta confirmed as Registrar in Bihar on that date.
State of Orissa rejected both claims of respondent.
Respondent filed writ petition under Art. 226 in Orissa High Court (O.J.C. No. 270 of 1962).
High Court on 7th May 1963 rejected first claim (24th April 1954) but allowed alternative claim, directing refixation of pension treating confirmation from 23rd August 1956.
Orissa High Court granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.
In 1954, Public Service Commission recommended respondent fit as Registrar for stop-gap only, not to be given preference over higher listed officers even for vacancies over 4 months.
Mr. Beuria, another transferred officer junior in Bihar promoted, held entitled to Registrar pay from 1st December 1948 retrospectively by order dated 12th October 1960.
Protection Rules issued by Governor-General in Council on 15th September 1936 under section 23(2) of Government of India (Construction of Orissa) Order, 1936.

legal_issues.text: Construction of Rule 6 of the Protection Rules: whether it protects conditions of service including claims for promotion to higher selection posts and confirmation therein, particularly for determining pension by reference to hypothetical promotion dates in Bihar.
Whether treatment of respondent discriminatory compared to junior officers in Bihar or other cases like Mr. Beuria.

petitioner_arguments.text: Rule 6 protects only pay, allowances, leave and pension as they were before 1st April 1936; does not include promotion to selection posts which depend on vacancies, seniority, merits, etc.
Cannot indirectly claim promotion via pension calculation by comparing to Bihar promotions of juniors; impractical and outside Rule 6.
No radical difference in Bihar R. 2(1) and Orissa Rules 6-9 for promotion; no evidence of prejudice.
Mr. Beuria case outside Rule 6; single misconstrual does not justify similar treatment for all.

respondent_arguments.text: Deem confirmation as Registrar from 24th April 1954 or at latest 23rd August 1956 when junior Mr. J.N. Dutta confirmed in Bihar, affecting pension.
Bihar promotion rules (R. 2(1)) differ radically from Orissa Rules 6-9, allowing wider selection pool, contravening Rule 6 protections.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 6 of Protection Rules; Bihar R. 2(1); Orissa Rules 6-9

respondent_arguments.text: Discriminatory treatment as junior Mr. Dutta and Mr. Beuria (junior in Bihar) got benefits.

court_reasoning.text: High Court incorrectly assumed Rule 6 covers promotion claims and relevant to inquire hypothetical Bihar promotion date; Rule 6 guarantees only pay, allowances, leave, pension conditions, not selection post promotions which involve multiple factors.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Promotion to selection post outside terms of R. 6; cannot indirectly claim via pension bearing.

court_reasoning.text: No material shows radical difference in promotion rules between Bihar and Orissa; selection involves seniority-cum-merit in both.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Respondent's PSC recommendation in 1954 limited him to stop-gap due to record.

court_reasoning.text: Mr. Beuria case irrelevant as misconstrual in one case does not bind similar misconstrual; no evidence of broader discrimination.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Discrimination plea requires evidence, not single instance.

holdings.text: Rule 6 does not protect promotion/confirmation to selection posts or allow pension calculation by hypothetical Bihar promotion dates of juniors.

statutes_cited.name: Protection Rules, 1936
statutes_cited.relevance: Conditions of service (pay, allowances, leave, pension) not less favourable than before 1st April 1936 for transferred officers; does not extend to selection promotions.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India (Construction of Orissa) Order, 1936

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order dated May 7, 1963 set aside; respondent's writ petition dismissed. Pension fixation by State of Orissa upheld.

key_quotes.text: What R. 6 guarantees is that the public servants who were transferred to Orissa will not suffer in regard to their pay, allowances, leave and pension these respective conditions did not include a claim for promotion to a higher selection post
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core interpretation limiting scope of Rule 6

key_quotes.text: As promotion to a selection post was outside the terms of R. 6, a claim for promotion could not be indirectly permitted on the ground that it had a bearing on the amount of pension
key_quotes.speaker: court
